sense.name: hit forcefully; deliver a sharp blow or push
sense.commentary: Includes: KNOCK AGAINST, KNOCK DOWN, KNOCK OUT, KNOCK OVER, KNOCK AROUND Note: Also includes the meaning: "produce an opening by hitting forcefully". NOTE: PLEASE compare carefully to VPCs in other sense--there may be different uses of VPCs. Think these over carefully before preceding! Taggers are encouraged to make written notes of VPCs to refer to while tagging.
sense.examples: He accidentally knocked the vase off the table. She knocked her head against the wall as she fell. Who knocked over that mug of coffee? Some thug knocked him unconscious. They knocked nails into the wall. He knocked me off balance. She was knocked down by a bus. The winds knocked out the window. She easily knocked down every argument he put up. He used to be a bully in school. He knocked me about all the time. He got arrested for knocking around his wife. He knocked out his pipe. The landlord knocked a hole in the wall at the back of the premises.

sense.name: tap, rap or clank repeatedly producing noise
sense.examples: She knocked on the window to attract his attention. There's someone knocking at the door. Please knock before entering. The heater in my dormroom has been knocking all afternoon. The car engine is knocking again.

sense.name: find fault with; express criticism of
sense.examples: Don't knock him. He's doing his best. Don't knock the food. It's free.

sense.name: wander from place to place; hang out; kick about
sense.examples: I'm sure I've got a copy of 'Time's Arrow' knocking about somewhere. He spent years knocking around the Far East before World War One. I used to knock around with him at school.

sense.name: set someone back physically, emotionally, or financially
sense.examples: I bet that computer knocked you back a few thousand. Wow, a bout with a bad cold really knocked me back for a couple of weeks.

sense.name: eliminate (not kill), render unconcious, overwhelm
sense.commentary: Is: KNOCK COLD, KNOCK OUT NOTE: this 'render unconscious' often is a result of being 'knocked down' and may be confused with sense 1; sense 1 ONLY has the implication of being hit (you may be knocked down without being made unconscious) but the additional inference of being knocked unconscious is in this sense
sense.examples: The Brazilian team was unexpectedly knocked out in the first round. The car moving at 35 miles per hour struck him and knocked him out cold. All the guys were knocked out by her charm.

sense.name: kill
sense.examples: He hired a hit-man to knock off a business rival.

sense.name: reduce or cut quantitatively
sense.examples: She wanted to knock down the price to $200. The manager knocked off $5 because it was damaged.

sense.name: steal or copy illegally
sense.examples: He has a stack of computer equipment he's knocked off from various shops. Terrorist groups are knocking over banks to get money. He got in trouble for knocking off name brand purses.

sense.name: accomplish quickly
sense.examples: She knocked the project together in 3 days. I can knock that proposal out by tomorrow. She knocked off a letter to her brother that afternoon.

sense.name: (cause to) become pregnant
sense.examples: You don't want to get knocked up by some guy you hardly know.

sense.name: Ingest.
sense.examples: I love doughnuts. I could knock back five or six. I knocked back a few beers before heading home.
